Award.AwardTitle: Sources of Particulate Organic Matter and Their Use by Suspension-feeders in New Zealand Kelp Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this proposal is to catalyze a research collaboration between the PI and Dr. Nicholas Shears, a Lecturer at the University of Auckland, to understand trophic connections and the effect of resource variability on consumers. This is necessary to predict how food webs may shift in the face of environmental change. The PI proposes to extend prior work to examine the role of kelp detritus in this very different kelp forest system. He will use stable isotopes and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trace kelp carbon through the food web, and test the hypothesis that kelp detritus represents a significant source of carbon to suspension feeders living in the extensive Ecklonia kelp forests of New Zealand. This award is supported by the Catalyzing New International Collaborations program under OIIA/International Science and Engineering, with co-funding by GEO/Ocean Sciences.

Macroalgae and phytoplankton support highly productive marine ecosystems on shallow coastal reefs. The objectives of the proposed research are to determine: (1) the contribution of phytoplankton and kelp detritus to the pool of suspended particulate organic matter (POM) available to reef consumers, and (2) how different components of the POM are used as food by reef suspension feeders. Broader impacts of this project will include educational benefits to a graduate student who is the first person in her family to attend college. The project will serve to expand her research and perspective to include a very different kelp forest system and introduce her to the value of international collaborations through mentoring by Dr. Shears and his group. Results of this research will be disseminated widely through scientific publications but also through our undergraduate teaching and public lectures at venues such as the Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our overarching goal in this project was to to determine the extent to which kelp drives spatial and temporal dynamics of particulate organic matter (POM) and to what extent reef suspension feeders use kelp detritus as food in a kelp forest system in New Zealand.  We used complementary tracer approaches, stable isotopes and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), to identify different sources of coastal POM and how they contribute to the diet of suspension-feeders on New Zealand rocky reefs. We also conducted a controlled laboratory experiment evaluating the effect of kelp on the growth and survival of reef suspension feeders, in parallel with a similar experiment conducted in California. we designed and executed an experiment in which we outplanted mussels and oysters eight sites spanning a gradient in phytoplankton productivity, from a nutrient-rich emabayment (Meola Reef) to relatively oligotrophic open water (Goat Island).  After we left, a New Zealand Ph.D. student built on this experiment and maintained it as part of her PhD project. We worked with our collaborators r on two preproposals to the Marsden Foundation, the equivalent to NSF in New Zealand.In doing this work we developed a continuing collaboration with colleagues in New Zealand.  Significant experience with international collaboration was also gained by a graduate student and an undergraduate.  The undergraduate continued into graduate school in marine science partially because of the positive experience she gained from this project.  This CNIC project allowed us to develop new international collaborations and collect data that we are now using to write research proposals that will sustain the collaboration over the long term.
